page.title: 19TRANSPORT IN DOLPHINTON
page.content: The railway had come and gone within the past 150 years. The Caledonian line from Carstairs met the N.B. railway to Leadburn, the line linking the two stations passing under the road bridge. Passenger service on the N.B. ceased in 1932 and on Cale, by then L.M.S. in the 1940's. Buses to Edinburgh and Biggar started around 1926 becoming the only public transport on the demise of the railways. The service is now reduced to 7 buses per day in either direction. This is mainly due to the increase in private motoring, the majority of households having at least one car, many commuting daily to Edinburgh. School children are taken by bus to Biggar or Peebles. All goods to and from the village are tranpsorted by road, and we have the services of a mobile bank and library.
